caption: This video narrative chronicles the challenges faced by a group of mother bats and their offspring during migration, encompassing threats from predators and the rigors of the journey itself. In the wilds of northern Canada, an annual migration of three million bats heads to the Asia-Pacific valley, marking one of the most dramatic episodes in their lifecycle. Notable insights include the bats' encounters with predators during migration, yet their remarkable composure amidst such threats, with maternal instincts playing a pivotal role in ensuring their young's safety. Throughout the migration, they confront challenges like food scarcity and seawater separation. Ten days into the journey, mother bats conduct tests on their offspring to determine their readiness for migration. Along the way, they confront other predators such as wolves. The intricacies of migration mean some bats could lose their way or get separated, yet their innate survival instincts drive them to persevere. Remarkably, the bats' migration spans over two thousand kilometers, representing one of the longest coastal movements among all creatures.
